name: Monomial conjecture
rephrased: For a commutative ring with enough structure (being Noetherian and local), if you have a set of parameters that define its dimension, then raising these parameters to high enough powers and considering certain algebraic combinations, you can never get something non-zero.
implication_form: If A is a Noetherian local ring of dimension d with parameters x1,...,xd, then for all positive integers t, the Tor module Tor_A^d(A/(x1,...,xd), A/(x1,...,xd)) tensored with the ring localized by the product of the xi's, raised to the power t, is zero.
explained: The Monomial Conjecture, proposed by Melvin L. Hochster, addresses the structure of certain ideals in commutative algebra. It states: Let A be a Noetherian local ring of Krull dimension d, and let x₁, ..., xₖ be a system of parameters for A (meaning (x₁, ..., xₖ) is an ideal defining the ring, and A/(x₁, ..., xₖ) is an Artinian ring). Then, for all positive integers t, the monomial x₁ᵗ ⋯ xₖᵗ is annihilated by the ideal (x₁, ..., xₖ). In other words, x₁ᵗ ⋯ xₖᵗ lies in the annihilator of the ideal (x₁, ..., xₖ) in A. This means that multiplication by x₁ᵗ ⋯ xₖᵗ sends every element of the ideal (x₁, ..., xₖ) to 0 in A.
